awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Investigating Changes in Students' Prior Mathematical Reasoning: An Exploration of Backward Transfer Effects in School Algebra
awd_abstract_narration:
As students learn new mathematical concepts, teachers need to ensure that prior knowledge and prior ways understanding are not negatively affected.  This award explores "backward transfer", or the ways in which new learning impacts previously-established ways of reasoning.  The PI will observe and evaluate students in four Algebra I classrooms as they learn quadratic functions. The PI will examine how different kinds of instruction about the new concept of quadratic functions helps or hinders students' prior mathematical knowledge of the previous concept of linear functions.  More generally, this award will contribute to the field of mathematics education by expanding the application of knowledge transfer, moving it from only a forward focused direction to include, also, a backward focused direction.  An advisory board of scholars with expertise in mathematics education, assessment, social interactions, quantitative reasoning and measurement will support the project.  The research will occur in diverse classrooms and result in presentations at the annual conferences of national organizations, peer-reviewed publications, as well as a website for teachers which will explain both the theoretical model and the findings from the project.  An undergraduate university course and professional development workshops using video data from the project are also being developed for pre-service and in-service teachers.  Ultimately, the research findings will generate new knowledge and offer guidance to elementary school teachers as they prepare their students for algebra.  

The research involves three phases.  The first phase includes observations and recordings of four Algebra I classrooms and will test students' understanding of linear functions before and after the lessons on quadratic functions.  This phase will also include interviews with students to better understand their reasoning about linear function problems.  The class sessions will be coded for the kind of reasoning that they promote.  The second phase of the project will involve four cycles of design research to create quadratic and linear function activities that can be used as instructional interventions.  In conjunction with this phase, pre-service teachers will observe teaching sessions through a course that will be offered concurrently with the design research.  The final phase of the project will involve pilot-applied research which will test the effects of the instructional activities on students' linear function reasoning in classroom settings.  This phase will include treatment and control groups and further test the hypotheses and instructional products developed in the first two phases.

The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects

por.por_cntn:
With this project, we set out to better understand the phenomenon called backward transfer in the context of mathematics education. We define backward transfer as the influence that learning about new mathematics concepts has on students’ ways of reasoning about previously learned-about mathematics concepts.

Backward transfer represents an almost entirely unexplored frontier in education, a distinction few topics in education can claim. Our research program stands alone in making the study of backward transfer its primary focus. As a consequence, we lead the field of education by a considerable margin in examining this new frontier.

Our examination of backward transfer has been situated in the context of how quadratic functions instruction influences students’ previously established ways of reasoning about linear functions. This is an important context in which to study backward transfer because (a) quadratic and linear functions are prominently featured in most algebra curricula, (b) if quadratic functions instruction tends to unproductively influence students’ ways of reasoning about linear functions, then better understanding backward transfer will help researchers and teachers find ways to mitigate or prevent those unproductive influences, and (c) if there are ways to design quadratics instruction that productively influences students’ ways of reasoning about linear functions, then research is needed to discover/develop those ways. Thus, research on backward transfer in this context has the potential to greatly improve student outcomes in algebra.

Our project began with an examination of what happens in real classrooms to students’ previously established ways of reasoning about linear functions when teachers deliver business-as-usual quadratics instruction. Results showed that business-as-usual quadratics instruction produced unintended backward transfer. Specifically, how students conceived of linear functions as actions or as processes were unintentionally influenced (Hohensee et al., 2021), as was how they reasoned covariationally about linear functions (Hohensee, Willoughby, & Gartland, 2024). Additionally, we found that the backward transfer produced in real classrooms was non-uniform, meaning students’ ways of reasoning were influenced in different ways and different teachers produced different backward transfer influences.

Subsequent to our examination of backward transfer in real classrooms, we designed our own quadratics instructional approach, with the explicit goal of producing backward transfer that would productively influence students’ previously established ways of reasoning about linear functions. We delivered that instruction to groups high school students and studied the backward transfer effects produced. When we compared the backward transfer produced by our instruction to the backward transfer produced in real classrooms, surprisingly our instruction produced less backward transfer than the real classrooms produced (Hohensee, Gartland et al., accepted). However, the backward transfer we produced was more uniform and more productive than in real classrooms. These findings show it is possible to design instruction that produce productive backward transfer.

During our examination of the effects our instruction, we noticed that backward transfer played out differently for students whose incoming linear function reasoning was more developed than for those whose incoming linear function reasoning was less developed (Hohensee, Melville et al., accepted). Therefore, we engaged in a secondary analysis and found students at each level of development of their linear function reasoning who exhibited productive backward transfer. However, we also found that at different levels the productive backward transfer was different. These findings offer a more nuanced understanding for the range of backward transfer effects that can be produced with quadratics instruction.

Finally, we then set out to see if we could obtain statistically significant quantitative evidence of productive backward transfer with our quadratics instruction. Thus, after making small improvements to our instruction based on the previous implementation, we repeated our experiment. What we found was statistically significant evidence of productive backward transfer (Gartland, Hohensee, & Collier, 2024). This to our knowledge is the first quantitative evidence of intentionally producing backward transfer in a mathematics education context.

Our work on backward transfer is ongoing. We hope others will join us in exploring this new frontier.

 

Gartland, S., Hohensee, C., & Collier, C. (2024). Backward transfer influences from quadratic functions instruction on linear functions performance. Manuscript under review.

Hohensee, C., Melville, M., Collier, C. L., & Ma, Y. (accepted for publication). Backward transfer influences from quadratic functions instruction on levels of linear function reasoning abilities. To appear in the Journal for Research in Mathematics Education.

Hohensee, C., Gartland, S., Melville, M., & Willoughby, L. (accepted for publication). Contrasting cases as a mechanism for theory development of backward transfer. To appear in Research in Mathematics Education.

Hohensee, C., Willoughby, L., & Gartland, S. (2024). Backward transfer effects on ways of reasoning about linear functions with instruction on quadratic functions. Mathematical Thinking and Learning, 26(1), 71–89. https://doi.org/10.1080/10986065.2022.2037043

Hohensee, C., Gartland, S., Willoughby, L., & Melville, M. (2021). Backward transfer influences from quadratic functions instruction on students’ prior ways of covariational reasoning about linear functions. Journal of Mathematical Behavior, 61. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jmathb.2020.100834
